citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Per a facility representative, during the month of August 2023, a 15-year-old female Shih tzu named “Doodle” abruptly
loss the ability to use her hind limbs and could no longer walk. This lasted for a few weeks until she eventually passed
away. The licensee did not consult with a veterinarian in order to obtain a diagnosis or treatment plan. The licensee
treated the dog by supplementing daily with Chlorine Dioxide without prior veterinarian approval. Since a veterinarian was
not consulted, the licensee did not obtain an appropriate diagnosis or treatment plan that may have helped the animal’s
condition or reduced her pain/discomfort. The licensee must develop an adequate program of veterinary care that
includes the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases as well as injuries per the
attending veterinarian’s guidance.

At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have a written contingency plan in place. Without this tool, animals may
suffer illness, or injury due to unpreparedness should an emergency or disaster occur. The licensee must develop,
document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and
care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.

At the time of inspection, the following deficiencies were identified with the program of veterinary care.
- Per the licensee, the veterinarian has not visited the premises for a few years, a period extending the required 12
months.
- The plan does not include a vaccination schedule for contagious/deadly diseases (including rabies, parvovirus and
distemper) and does not describe the sampling as well as treatment plan for parasites and other pests (including fleas,
worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm).
- The plan did not contain instructions on preventative care and treatment to ensure that dogs have healthy/unmated
coats, properly trimmed nails, clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth.
- The medical records for both dogs were incomplete and did not fully describe for each entry the problem, examination
findings, test results, plan for treatment and care and treatment procedures performed, when appropriate.
Without a fully developed/documented care plan, animal health and well-being cannot be assured. In conjunction with the
attending veterinarian, the facility must establish programs of adequate veterinary care for the dogs and maintain
documentation of all the required elements.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 22, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
